user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_QueuePut_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_QueuePut_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, const void *data, size_t size, uint32 flags)
{
    int32                            return_code;
    int                              result;
    struct timespec                  ts;
    OS_impl_queue_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_queue_table, *token);

    /*
     * NOTE - using a zero timeout here for the same reason that QueueGet does ---
     * checking the attributes and doing the actual send is non-atomic, and if
     * two threads call QueuePut() at the same time on a nearly-full queue,
     * one could block.
     */
    memset(&ts, 0, sizeof(ts));

    /* send message */
    do
    {
        result = mq_timedsend(impl->id, data, size, 1, &ts);
    } while (result == -1 && errno == EINTR);

    if (result == 0)
    {
        return_code = OS_SUCCESS;
    }
    else if (errno == ETIMEDOUT)
    {
        return_code = OS_QUEUE_FULL;
    }
    else
    {
        /* Something else went wrong */
        return_code = OS_ERROR;
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No compiler language extensions are used in this function. The code contains: standard C constructs (typedef-like names int32/uint32 and size_t, struct declaration, local variable declarations), POSIX APIs/macros (struct timespec, mq_timedsend, errno, EINTR, ETIMEDOUT), and project macros (OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET) — none of which are compiler-specific language extensions. There are no occurrences of known compiler extensions such as __attribute__, __asm__, typeof, statement-expressions ({ ... }), nested functions, inline assembly, GCC/Clang builtins, zero-length arrays, or other vendor-specific keywords. The usage of memset, do/while, and the macros/typedefs shown are standard and not listed as compiler extensions in mainstream compiler documentation, so no fragments require investigation for Rule 1.2.
